Award.AwardTitle: SEES Fellows: Sustainable Infrastructure in a Changing Climate

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is supported under the NSF Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability Fellows (SEES Fellows) program, with the goal of helping to enable discoveries needed to inform actions that lead to environmental, energy and societal sustainability while creating the necessary workforce to address these challenges. Sustainability science is an emerging field that addresses the challenges of meeting human needs without harm to the environment, and without sacrificing the ability of future generations to meet their needs. A strong scientific workforce requires individuals educated and trained in interdisciplinary research and thinking, especially in the area of sustainability science. With the SEES Fellowship support, this project will enable a promising early career researcher to establish herself in an independent research career related to sustainability.

This project addresses the need of incorporating climate trends and projections to ensure the sustainability of long-term planning in the infrastructure sector. For infrastructure in particular (e.g., roads, bridges, culverts, and storm drainage systems), future change may shift many of these risks beyond historical and even current design standards. Modifying existing infrastructure and ensuring new construction will be adapted to future change is a central and critical concern surrounding the issues of infrastructure resiliency and sustainable infrastructure design. The proposed work will combine state-of-the-art models and tools in climate change research with engineering know-how to help design stronger and longer-lasting infrastructure for the future. Advances in both high-resolution climate modeling and implementation of climate projections in infrastructure engineering will enhance collaboration efforts within the ICNet RCN and significantly contribute towards the science of sustainable engineering under changing environmental conditions. This proposal aims to reduce the knowledge gap between climate scientists and engineers and to address specific challenges that climate change poses to infrastructure engineering. It will explore the ways in which climate information can be used to inform design standards to build better bridges and roads that will last longer in the future and require less money and energy to maintain.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF-SEES Project Outcomes Report

Sustainable Infrastructure in a Changing Climate: Dismantling the Knowledge Barrier between Infrastructure Engineering and Climate Science

 

Since preindustrial times the average temperature of the Earth has warmed by 1?C, resulting in impacts already observed across the globe due to increases in the average temperature, prolonged heatwaves and drought, as well as changes in precipitation patterns and more frequent and extreme precipitation events. Climate models project that these trends are expected to continue and most regions in the U.S. should anticipate even further and more severe impacts due to climate change in the coming decades. 

Transportation infrastructure, built to last many decades, is a vital component of the everyday lives of people. Infrastructure design depends on the climate for which it is being built in order to withstand potential extreme weather events that could affect the durability of the asset. Disruptions caused by premature failing or repairs of infrastructure built without consideration for changes in future climate will impact personal travel as well as transportation of good and services.

Many infrastructure engineers are interested in incorporating climate projections into their design process but are uncertain of how to do so. Climate scientists, on the other hand, work on generating high-resolution climate projection datasets, but not with infrastructure engineering particularly in mind. Bridging this gap between what engineers need and what climate scientist can provide, as well as expanding the communication and understanding of each other?s fields has been a major focus of this project. 

The project proposed to work with a widely accepted pavement design model using specifically tailored climate projections as an input to examine the potential impact of locally changing future climate to the performance and lifetime of asphalt pavement. Working with a pavement expert at the University of New Hampshire, I generated locally relevant pavement designs for both an interstate and a primary road pavement for 24 cities across the country, using current design standards and historical climate information, as is also standard. To generate local climate projections for each site I used a novel statistical downscaling method called Seasonal Trends and Analysis of Residuals Empirical Statistical Downscaling Model (STAR-ESDM), which has been designed by myself and colleagues at Texas Tech University. The downscaling model generates daily climate projections; however, the pavement model requires hourly climate input, which is generally not a problem when using historical observations, but this high temporal resolution is not available for future climate projections. I therefore developed and applied a variety of techniques to render the daily projections to an hourly timestep before it could be used in the pavement model. This resulted in hourly climate projections for five climate variables for one global climate model (GCM) and one higher future scenario that was used as input to the pavement model to examine the impact on the performance and lifetime of the pavement for three future periods (2001-2020, 2041-2060, and 2081-2100) and compared with a baseline period (1981-2000) at each of the 24 locations. The process and results are described in Stoner et al. (2019), which shows that, using current design standards will generally result in reduced performance and lifetime with larger impacts toward the end of the century and at higher latitudes. The study was expanded to look at the impact on three different levels of global mean temperature change, using climate projections for 14 GCMs and 2 future scenarios for a more complete study. The initial work has been presented at both an atmospheric science conference as well as an engineering conference.

Being part of the interdisciplinary NSF-funded Regional Climate Network the Infrastructure and Climate Network (ICNet) has been a fundamental resource for this work with its 50+ members coming from both academia and the professional world and from both the engineering sector as well as the climate science community. I have learned a tremendous amount from the engineers and together we have built trust between the scientific and engineering communities. I have taught several workshops to the engineers in the group on climate science as well as how to properly work with climate projections and the engineers are now comfortable asking for advice or collaboration when including climate projections in their work. The work with ICNet has also resulted several opportunities to disseminate the message of incorporating climate projections into infrastructure design to the engineering community with two invited talks at engineering conferences as well as two invited live webinars distributed to civil engineers across the country.

Another outcome is the forthcoming release of a high-resolution projected dataset for tens of thousands of stations across North America as well as grids covering the entire contiguous U.S. and lower Canada for temperature and precipitation using more than 20 climate models, which is expected to be available for download in early 2020 free of charge.
